Policy Statement
It is the George C. Marshall Space Flight Center's (MSFC) and National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) policy to conduct operations involving toxic and flammable substances safely, reducing to the greatest extent possible any hazards associated with the processes; and reducing any subsequent risk to the surrounding community, personnel, and the environment.  The policy includes working with the surrounding community and local emergency response agencies to promote a spirit of cooperation and teamwork, and to orchestrate an effective contingency plan in the unlikely event of a process incident occurring at MSFC.

Description of Facility and Regulated Substance Handled
MSFC is one of the largest and most complex of NASA's nine centers.  MSFC is NASA's principal propulsion development center and plays a major role in the National Space Transportation System, managing the Space Shuttle's main engines, solid rocket boosters, and external tank.  In addition, MSFC will be a significant contributor to several of NASA's future programs, including the development of advanced propulsion systems and planetary observatories and research on a variety of space science applications.  
Liquid hydrogen and liquid natural gas, both flammable, are stored at MSFC and used in rocket engine testing and research activities.  Liquid propane, a flammable substance, also is stored at MSFC and used for process heating and welding.  In addition, acetylene is stored at MSFC, but the storage quantity does not exceed the RMP threshold quantity (TQ).  None of the toxic substances stored at MSFC exceed the RMP TQs.  

Program 3 Substance
Liquid hydrogen is subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standards.  The maximum quantity of liquid hydrogen that can be stored at the facility is 431,644 pounds.  The liquid hydrogen storage details are as follows:
7 Building 4517-One mothballed (inactive) storage tank with a c

apacity of 75,000 gallons (44,250 pounds)
7 Building 4527-One mothballed (inactive) storage tank with a capacity of 100,000 gallons (59,000 pounds)
7 Building 4672-Two storage spheres with a capacity of 225,000 gallons each (132,750 pounds each)
7 Building 4657-One storage tank with a capacity of 35,000 gallons (20,650 pounds), one storage tank with a capacity of 12,000 gallons (7,080 pounds), and one storage tank with a capacity of 4,000 gallons (2,360 pounds)
7 Building 4696-One storage tank with a capacity of 28,000 gallons (16,520 pounds)
7 Portable Trailers-Two trailers with a capacity of 7,800 gallons each (4,602 pounds each), and one trailer with a capacity of 12,000 gallons (7,080 pounds)
In addition 3,726 pounds of gaseous hydrogen can be stored in tanks and trailers in transit.

Program 2 Substances 
Liquid Natural Gas
The maximum quantity of liquid natural gas that can be stored is 113,280 pounds and the storage details are described below:
7 Building 4583-One mothballed (inactive) storage tank with a capacity of 28,000 gallons (99,120 pounds)
7 Building 4657-One storage tank with a capacity of 4,000 gallons (14,160 pounds)
7 Propulsion Lab (Test Stand 115)-One storage tank with a capacity of 2,200 gallons (7,788 pounds)

Propane
The maximum storage quantity of propane is 273,760 pounds in 32 tanks with capacities of 100 gallons, 150 gallons, 200 gallons, 250 gallons, 300 gallons, 500 gallons, and 1,000 gallons.

Safety and Specifications
The liquid hydrogen and liquid natural gas systems consist of pressure/vacuum relief valves, bypass relief valves, excess flow valves, pressure and temperature indicators, leak detectors, alarms, manual and automatic control systems, burnstacks, and all necessary safeguards for the safe operation of the systems.  The liquid hydrogen and natural gas storage systems and associated processes are designed and installed in accordance with NASA and industry-specific design standards.  Where applicable, the manufacturer's speci

fications are incorporated into the standard operating procedures (SOPs) for safe operation of the process.  The propane system consists of pressure/vacuum relief valves, bypass relief valves, excess flow valves, and pressure and temperature indicators.  National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) 58 standards are followed for the design and operation of propane systems.

Flammable Substance Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios

Worst-case Release Scenario (WRS)
The EPA-defined worst-case scenario (40 CFR 68.25 (2)) is the failure of the largest hydrogen container, resulting in a release of 132,750 pounds of hydrogen in 10 minutes.  The liquid hydrogen spheres are stored in an open diked area.  Therefore, passive mitigation is not considered.  

Distance to Endpoint
The distance to 1.0 psi overpressure is estimated using the vapor cloud explosion equation in EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance Document (1996).  The distance to 1.0 psi overpressure is calculated to be 0.57 mile, beyond which there will not be enough overpressure to pose a hazard to the public and buildings.  

Public Receptors
The total working population at MSFC affected by this hypothetical worst-case release is estimated to be 2,240 people, based on a work force of 6,400 MSFC and contractor personnel on duty every day.  No offsite residential population is affected.  

Environmental Receptors
The worst-case release would affect the Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge.  Realistically, MSFC does not anticipate that the worst-case scenario could actually happen.  In the event of a total rupture of the liquid hydrogen storage sphere, much of the liquid hydrogen will freeze and dissipate over a period of several hours.  The worst-case scenario assumes that the total quantity forms a vapor cloud and that the total quantity in the cloud at the flammability limit is unrealistic.  

Additional Worst-case Release Scenarios
No additional worst-case scenarios are developed because no offsite publi

c receptor is affected.

Alternative Release Scenario (ARS)
MSFC has developed an ARS based on the requirements of 40 CFR 68.28 for liquid hydrogen that is a more realistic "worst-case" scenario, based on actual operating experience.  This scenario is more likely to occur and can reach an endpoint offsite.  The scenario involves the release of liquid hydrogen through the insulation surrounding the bellows connected to the liquid hydrogen tank.  It is assumed that 900 gallons of liquid hydrogen will leak out in 60 seconds.  The release rate is 241 kilograms per minute (531 pounds per minute).  Normally, the release is vented to a flare.  However, in this case, the leakage rate is assumed to exceed the vent system capability.  

Distance to Endpoint
The distance to 1.0 psi overpressure is estimated using Look-up Table 18 of the EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance Document (1996).  The distance to 1.0 psi overpressure is estimated to be 0.20 mile, beyond which there will not be enough overpressure to pose a hazard to the public.

Public Receptors
The total working population at MSFC affected by this ARS is estimated to be 280 people, based on a work force of 6,400 MSFC and contractor personnel on duty every day.  No offsite residential population is affected.  

Environmental Receptors
The alternative release also would affect the Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge, which is an environmental receptor.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
MSFC is in compliance with the RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.  The facility has conducted a comprehensive review of all systems, as well as of administrative, technical, and operating and maintenance procedures, in addition to the other required program elements of the RMP Rule.  

Safety Information
Detailed chemical safety and equipment safety information is compiled and readily available to operators and personnel involved in the operation and maintenance of the liquid hydrogen, liquid natura

l gas and propane systems.  Detailed engineering drawings of all the systems are readily available.

Process Hazard Analysis
A process hazard analysis was performed for the liquid hydrogen process (Program 3 process) at this facility using a checklist and by following the Guidelines of Organizational Work Instruction (NASA Document number S&MA-CR20-IS-N-015).  A hazard analysis also was conducted for the liquid natural gas and propane systems (Program 2 processes) using a checklist extracted from the Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures (written by JBF Associates, Inc., for American Institute of Chemical Engineers [AIChE]/Center for Chemical Process Safety [CCPS]).  

Operating Procedures
Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) that define how tasks related to the operation of the liquid hydrogen, liquid natural gas storage systems and the burnstack propane system are followed.  The SOPs are written based on NASA guidelines for pressure systems, and go through an approval process before implementation.  The SOPs cover all phases of operation, including initial startup, normal operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, startup following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations.

Training
Personnel whose job tasks are related to the operation and maintenance of the liquid hydrogen, liquid natural gas and the burnstack propane systems are given class room and on-the-job training.  The training program includes both initial and refresher training.  The training program is approved by NASA and is revised when process or equipment changes occur.  Written tests, oral tests, demonstration and observation are used to verify that the personnel understand the training material before they can resume work on the systems.

Mechanical Integrity
NASA guidelines are followed for maintaining the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger personnel, public and the environment.  The mechanical integrity pro

gram includes an inspection, testing and recertification of the storage systems and equipment to help identify equipment deterioration, malfunction and damage.   The mechanical integrity program also includes a quality assurance program to ensure that the liquid hydrogen and liquid natural gas meet the NASA quality specifications, and new and replacement equipment meet the design standards.

Management of Change
All proposed changes to the equipment and SOPs are evaluated and approved following NASA guidelines to ensure that the change does not adversely affect the safety of operations.

Pre-startup Review
A safety review of a new or modified process is performed following NASA guidelines before the system is brought into service.  This review confirms that the design and construction of the equipment is in accordance with the design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; employee training has been completed; and a process hazard analysis has been completed. 

Compliance Audit
Compliance audit of all liquid hydrogen, liquid natural gas and the burnstack propane systems are conducted per schedule to ensure that the prevention program effectively addresses the safety of the storage systems.  The audit is conducted by people knowledgeable in the process and reviewed by NASA personnel.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved following a schedule developed, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.

Incident Investigation
MSFC investigates all incidents that could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team initiates the investigation within 48 hours of the incident.  The incidents are documented in the Incident Reporting and Information System (IRIS) and the incident investigation results are documented in the Lessons Learned System (LLIS).

Employee Participation

MSFC has guidelines to ensure employee participation in pressure system operations.  All employee concerns are addressed promptly.  The pressure systems contractor responsible for the liquid hydrogen and liquid natural gas storage and supply systems, and burnstack propane system implements employee participation procedures to ensure the safety concerns of personnel.  MSFC and the contractor encourage active participation of personnel in the prevention program activities of the liquid hydrogen, liquid natural gas, and the burnstack propane systems.

Hot Work Permits
Following the MSFC guidelines, the pressure systems contractor follows an established hot work permit, and lockout-tagout procedure to control spark- or flame- producing activities that could result in fires or explosion in any of the pressure systems.  Non-sparking tools are used at the facility during maintenance activities.  Hot work permit and lockout-tagout forms must be filled out and approved by the supervisor before any maintenance activity is commenced.

Contractors
MSFC has a program with procedures to ensure that contractor activities are performed in a safe manner.  The safety record of contractors is reviewed annually.

Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
In addition to the Program Level 3 elements required for liquid hydrogen and Program Level 2 elements required for liquid natural gas and propane, MSFC has implemented safety features specific to the flammable substance handled according to NASA guidelines.  The burnstack serves to burn off liquid hydrogen, when necessary, in a safe way.  Leak detectors and flame detectors are provided to ensure safety of the process and personnel.

Five-year Accident History
Since June 1994, MSFC has not had a release of liquid hydrogen, liquid natural gas, or propane that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Emergen

cy Response Program
MSFC has an Emergency Response Program (MM 1040.3F, MSFC Emergency Plan) that coordinates response efforts with the Redstone Arsenal Fire Department (RSA FD), the Protective Services Office, the medical center, and the Eggerton, Germishausen and Greer (EG&G) Incident/Spill Response Team.  Response activities also have been discussed with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and with state and local governments.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
MSFC has already installed the necessary equipment and the operating and training procedures required for the safe operation of the liquid hydrogen (Program Level 3 process) and of the liquid natural gas and propane (Program Level 2 processes) systems.  The process hazard analysis and the certification surveillance found minor discrepancies of pressure system components such as corrosion, calibration, labeling, and undersizing.  The expected date of correction of discrepancies is December 1999.
